In pasture, located on a ridge, just below and to E of the highest point, close to the break of slope where ground falls away to S, giving excellent views over the Palmerstown River estuary and Kilalla Bay. Nephin and the Nephin Beg mountain range define the far horizon to S-SW. There is a mound (MA015-025002-) 50m to SW. This stone circle is a National Monument in State ownership (No. 389). It is indicated as ‘Cromlech’ on the 1838 OS 6-inch map where it is depicted as simple circle. It, and the adjacent mound (MA015-026002-), are indicated as ‘Cromlechs’ and are both depicted as rough circles of boulders on the 25-inch plan; on the 1922 6-inch edition the stone circle is marked with a dolmen-type symbol. De Valera & Ó Nualláin (1964, 94) record this stone circle as follows: ‘Marked ‘cromlech’ on the O.S.6” 1837. This is the more northerly of the two monuments marked under the name ‘Cromlechs’ in Rathfran in the current edition [1922] of the map. It is a stone circle consisting of some sixteen stones five of which are now prostrate. Those remaining erect are from 0.5 m. to 1.60 m. high. The stones vary from 0.85 m to 2.00 m. in length and from .40 m. to 1.2m. in thickness. The area enclosed measures 17.00 m. (N-S) by 19.00 m. (E-W).’  An inspection in 1994 recorded the stone circle as a  circular area (19.5m E-W; 19m N-S) defined by a broad, low bank (Wth 4-5m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.4m at N, 1.1m at S) in which are set twelve upright boulders. The boulders are rounded or irregular in form, and vary in size (Circ. c. 2.5-4m) and height (0.8-1.45m). They are set at irregular intervals around the circumference of the bank, some set against the inner face, but others set in the bank. Two large prostrate stones and a number of smaller stones protrude randomly from the bank, some or all of which may be the result of field clearance. The bank is generally rather low and degraded; there are two corresponding gaps (Wth 2-2.5m) at the E and W.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 28 November 2017

In pasture, located on a level elevated ground overlooking the estuary of the Palmerstown River to S-SE. A few meters to SE there is a gradual fall of ground, in gentle undulations, towards the river. Nephin and the Nephin Beg range are visible to S-SW. A wedge tomb (MA015-027001) is located c. 30-40m to SW. This was described in the 1838 OS Letters as a 'monument which does not appear to preserve its original form.' (O’Flanagan, 1927, 183-4 (98)).  It was classed as a stone circle by de Valera & Ó Nualláin (1964, 32) and recorded as follows: 'Marked "Cromlech" on O.S. 6" 1837. This monument, which was a stone circle, has been totally removed since 1951 and the debris from it has been dumped on the east end of the nearby tomb [MA015-027001-]."  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 15 November 2018

Situated on a N-facing slope of high ground overlooking a valley to the N with a nearby stream to the E in a mountainous area. A circular area (diam. 12.5m) enclosed by eleven orthostats ranging in height from 0.15m to 2m with several prostrate stones around the perimeter of the circle. A large, flat, recumbent stone lies in cente of circle. (Ó Nualláin 1987, 142-4)  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated on reclaimed grassland on S facing slope of rising ground in upland area. Boulder Burial (TN038-004) alignment located 300m to N of site of Stone circle. All that remains of the stone circle is a deep pit (int. dims. 0.8m x 0.8m x D 1.4m) lined with concrete surround (T 0.2m) which is level with the existing ground surface with a triangular-shaped recumbent limestone slab (dims.L 1.2m; Wth 1m; T 0.3m) acting as a cap stone lying over the concrete lined pit (see attached photo). Described by Rynne (1969, 90) as a small stone circle (diam. 4.5m) of seven stones (H 0.3m) with an outlier to the E. The recumbent slab now acting as a cap stone may be one of the orthostats of the stone circle described by Rynne in 1963. Inside the pit there is a small slab which may also have been one of the original orthostats. The land has been reclaimed and reseeded with grass which may have resulted in levelling of the stone circle. When the stone circle was being levelled the land owner may have come across a deep pit inside the circle which he may have then lined with concrete on top of which he placed one of the original orthostats of the circle. In Rynne's description of the site he mentions some irregularities in the ground inside the stone circle and suggested it may have been the remains of a cairn. Could the concrete lined pit be the remains of a cist which may have been converted into a concrete lined well during drainage of the field? The 1963 photo of the field shows it as a rough wet marshland which has subsequently been reclaimed.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

National Monument in state guardianship No. 416.  Disturbed remains of a circle of granite blocks (int. diam. 23m) at the high N end of a small steep-sided ridge. There are sixteen stones in the area of the site of which only five are in situ; of the others, five are prostrate but probably close to their original position, three are clearly displaced while the remaining two are too small to have been original components. The stones in situ vary in height from 1.3m to 1.92m but (contra Burl 1976, 234) the pair at the NE are not the highest stones in the circle although their position, facing the outlier ('The Piper') 40m further to the NE, suggests that they may mark the entrance. The OS Letters (O'Flanagan 1928, 114) describe twenty-nine stones including displaced examples and record a then recent attempt to plant the site with trees. A trench dug around the inner edge of the circle was noted and also the presence of a bank between the stones which may be the origin of the low bank now visible between the stones at the SE. The outlier (WI015-010001-) occurs downslope to the E and is a large cup-marked glacial erratic (H 1.95m; diam. c. 2.9m). While it is a natural feature there is no reason to believe that it did not form an integral part of the site. Crossing the top of the stone at right-angles are two well-defined grooves and a similar curved groove occurs on what was the top of a prostrate stone in the SE part of the circle. It is clear that these are not entirely natural.  (Burl 1976, 234; Walshe 1931, 128-30)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wicklow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 18 October 2017  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 97/1940).

Listed as a 'stone circle' in the SMR (1986) and as a possible 'stone circle' in the RMP (1995). On level to gently S-facing ground in a farmyard. This 'stone circle'  is reputed to have stood in front of the present house and to have been destroyed in 1952. It apparently consisted of a ring of forty small boulders ("few over 45cm (18") high") 9m (30') in diameter (ITA Survey 1943; Churcher 1985, 12-13). There is no visible surface indication of this monument.  Compiled by: Matt Kelleher  Date of upload: 20 December 2012

National Monument in state ownership No. 531.  Listed as a 'stone circle' in the SMR (1986) and as a possible 'stone circle' in the RMP (1995). On the saddle of a rocky E-W ridge with a marked slope to the S. A scatter of mainly split quartz boulders to the NE of enclosure (WI015-038----) which may be part of a displaced revetment. One of the boulder fragments has a curved groove (Wth 0.02m; D 0.01m) on its flat upper surface. Price (1934, 38-39) mentions that the 'circle' had a diameter of 'about 120 feet' (c. 36.5m) and was formed by twelve stones nearly all broken by blasting.  A single large stone ocurs to the SW (of WI015-038----).     Compiled by: Matt Kelleher  Date of upload: 21 December 2012  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 150/1940).

National Monument in state ownership No. 441.  Situated on a natural rise with gentle slopes to S, W and E and overlooking the River Slaney (250m to the S). The stone circle (diam. 30m) consists of large boulders, originally contiguous, some standing upright and others erected on their long axis. The circle is largely intact at the N but is less well-preserved to the S. It consists of twenty-nine substantial stones and a number of smaller fragments with some loose boulders occurring in the interior which is otherwise featureless. Wedge marks and boreholes in several stones indicate deliberate destruction. The entrance (Wth 1.3m) appears to be between two exceptionally large quartz boulders (L 2.4m and 3m; Wth 1.2m and 1.8m) at the E. Abutting onto the outer face of the circle is an earthen bank (diam. 40m; Wth 4.5m; max. H 1m), the terminals of which encompass the quartz boulders of the entrance. Some boulders along the outer edge of the bank may indicate an outer revetment. To the E of the entrance (at 15.8m) is a single upright stone. A field bank cuts across the outer edge of the bank at the S. The site occurs centrally within a well-defined cropmark enclosure (diam. c. 80m; CUCAP, BDR039) defined by a fosse (Wth c. 4-5m). Between this and the earthen bank is a narrower cropmark defined by a trench or narrow fosse (diam. c. 50m; Wth c. 1m). (Walshe 1931, 131-4; Leask 1945, 266-7; Burl 1993, 106, 240; 1995, 249-50)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wicklow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 30 June 2010 G. Conroy.  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 109/1940).

Situated in forestry on a low E-W ridge with extensive views to the N, E and S. Known locally as the 'Griddle Stones'. Circular site (int. diam. 13.5m) at present defined by eleven evenly spaced upright stones (1.3-1.8m apart). The entrance (Wth 1.3m) is at the SSW. The stones appear to rise in height from the entrance (H 1.3m) to the tallest stones (H 1.4-1.88m) at the NNE. The circle is on the inner edge of an earthen bank (Wth 1.75m (at the SE) to 2m (at the SW); H 0.4m). There are no stones in the NW quadrant or at E. A tumulus (WI027-040----) lies 75m to the E. Stone circle visited by Lisa Courtney in July 2019, February and August 2020 who described the monument as following. 'The site stands at the highest point of the pass between the Brusselstown Ring (405m) OD to the west and Keadeen Mountain (654m) OD to the east.   During the February visit, a low bank ranging in width from 1-2m and 200mm-400mm high could be discerned around the monument. The monument consists of 11 stone uprights with a single small recumbent stone (possible axial stone) located due north. The internal diameter of the site measures 12.5m east-west and 13m north-south. There is regular spacing between the six stones to the southwest of the circle (ranging from 1.0m-1.7m) with the tallest pointed stone located to the northeast (1.7m high, 1.12m wide and 250mm thick). To the south of this stone (1.50m), a partially buried stone was visible in the bank that surrounds the circle, the visible portion of this stone measures 1.10m in length and is approximately 600mm wide and 200mm thick. This may be a fallen stone belonging to this monument.  Price (1934) described the stone circle as follows: '45 feet [13.7m] in diameter, and approximately 140 feet [42.6m] in circumference; there are eleven stones standing, and there is the stump of a twelfth stone in the circle, almost level with the ground. The six stones standing on the west side are evenly spaced about 4 feet [1.2m] apart. The stone which stands to the NE of the centre of the circle is 6 feet 3 inches [1.9m] high, the other ten vary from 3 [0.9m] to 4.5 feet [1.4m] in height: the tall stone at the NE is pointed, of regular shape, with a flat inner face, which has natural markings caused by weathering running down it. The stones appear to be of local grit’.  Burl noted in his drawing of the stone circle, the remnants of a low bank behind the stones at Boleycarrigeen (Lynch 1979) and describes the site as being surrounded by a substantial bank about 1.8m wide and 0.9m high, making the site an excellent example of an embanked circle, similar to the Castleruddery stone circle (National Monument) which is located over 5km to the northwest. Both these stone circles form part of the Wicklow/ Kildare stone circle group, remarkable for their distinctive regional characteristics, and are the better-known examples in the group (Stout 1994).   Burl also records 11 stones and a stump, all of local shale, remaining out of a hypothetical 18 in a 13.9m diameter circle. The stones are evenly spaced approximately 1.2m apart (Burl 1995, 249).  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 106/1940). Situated on a low rise of ground in an area of rock outcrop overlooking a sea inlet known as Casloughtermon to the E. The ruins of Templecrone Church (DG048-008001-) can be seen 435m to the NE overlooking the N shoreline of Casloughtermon. The W shoreline of this inlet is 60m E of the possible stone circle.  An iregular shaped enclosure which may be the wall footings of a large house site (DG048-012----) are located c. 20m to the NE.  The site consists of a circular area (int. diam. c. 16m) enclosed by a circle of contiguous upright orthostats (avg. H 0.5m) with no evidence of an entrance gap into the circle.  In some places there is evidence or traces of a possible bank or small packing stones supporting the base of an on the external face of the upright stones.  The monument is located in a field known as the 'Rath Liath [Grey Fort]' (Pers. comm. J. Doherty 21/10/2011) and may be the remains of a denuded cashel rather than a stone circle but the lack of a clearly defined entrance feature and the single upright stones suggests that it may be the remains of a stone circle.   Compiled by Caimin O'Brien   Date of upload/revision: 27th October 2011

Situated on poorly drained grassland with possible moated site (WM031-115---) immediately to SSW.  Present remains consist of a circular area (diam. 7m) defined by 12 low circular shaped boulders (max. H 0.8m) set approx. 0.6-1.3m apart with single standing stone (H 0.5m) in centre of circle.  The stones are loosely placed on the ground and do not appear to be set into sockets.  The upright stone in the centre of the circle is also not set securely into the ground.  The shape of the boulders forming the circle and the way they are placed on the surface of the ground casts doubt on the antiquity of this monument.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly supplied by Melanie McQuade.  Date of upload: 22 March 2017

Situated on a slight SW-facing slope. Wright (1758, vol. 3, 9-10, pl. 3) records and illustrates the remains of two concentric stone circles enclosed by an earthen bank with an external fosse. Outside this earthwork is a further stone circle enclosing all the other monuments. All the features were open to the E in the eighteenth century, probably because they were damaged by an avenue leading to Carn House, which is marked on the 1835 edition of the OS 6-inch map, and which now leads to the clubhouse of a golf course. There was an entrance, undoubtedly original, in the earthen bank at W, but both internal stone circles may have had an entrance at NW. Morris records (1907, 1, 4, 61) that the monument was completely removed at that time, but he probably sought it in Ballynahattin townland.  However, a text analysis revealed that Wright placed the monument ‘on the Planes (sic) of Ballynahaitinne', not in that townland as such (Buckley 1988, 53-4). The site is now recognised as the cropmark of a complex enclosure identified from an aerial photograph (CUCAP: BGL, 40) in the adjacent townland of Carn Beg. The cropmark is of a large enclosure (diam. c. 110m) defined by the negative mark of what is probably a wide earthen bank and traces of a fosse feature. In the interior are the negative cropmarks of two concentric gapped features (ext. diam. c. 50m int. diam. c. 30m), undoubtedly the stone circles which are S of the centre of the embanked enclosure. Archaeological testing (96E0321) immediately outside the embanked enclosure to the S failed to produce any related material (Murphy 1996).  	  See the attached image from Wright's Louthiana  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 18 December 2017

Situated on elevated grassland known locally as 'Knockfleming', with panoramic views of the surrounding countryside from W-N-E.  Hilltop ringfort (LI014-069--) visible 440m to SSE.   Standing stones (LI014-140---/041/042-) in fields 290m to E. High Park House located 1.3km to NNE.   In 1826 it was recorded that there was a 'stone circle near High Park, the residence of Joseph Gabbett, Esq. where a number of stones are to be seen, some lying in confusion, others in circles or direct lines.  It is remarkable that they are all round, and one large stone [LI014-024----], detached from the rest, stands erect, which measures nine feet [3m] in height, nearly the same in breadth, and is four feet [1.2m] thick on one side' (Fitzgerald 1826, 288). Lynch suggested that this standing stone (LI014-024----) was the 'large central stone of the stone circle' and that 'the other stones were removed many years ago' (Lynch 1896, 467).  A low scarp visible in places suggests the existence of an embanked stone circle or hilltop enclosure encircling this impressive standing stone.   Lynch (1911-13, 26) suggested that these stones were removed from Knockfleming 'over sixty years ago [c. 1850]'.   Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien   Date of upload: 22 January 2019

Situated on a slight E-facing slope. Issac Butler, writing in 1744 (Deane 1922, 99), noted ‘an arch (arc) of stones 7 paces (c. 5.25m) in diameter’ about 40 yards (c. 36m) to the SE of the standing stone (LH011-020----). The stones are described by Butler as being almost covered with grass but ‘pitched on end’, by which he meant upright. There is no evidence of such a feature now but it could have been a small stone circle like a kerb-circle. However, it is not extant and its precise location cannot be provided. (Gosling 2018, 175)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of  upload; 17 January 2020

Situated in boggy pasture, in a clearing partially enclosed by trees.. A stone circle (diam. 8.5–9m) composed of 8 stones (H: c.0.4–1.2m), the highest of which is located at N. Each of the stones is lichen encrusted on all sides which suggests the stones have been in their current positions for a long period of time. Packing stones are not visible. This stone circle is not characteristic of the multiple stone circles of Cork and Kerry in that it is composed of an even rather than an uneven number of stones and does not have a recumbent stone at SW. A fire setting in the centre of the stone circle appears modern. Immediately S of the circle is a low heap of modern field clearance material consisting of loose boulders and vegetation. A table-top boulder directly S of this heap has possibly been recently placed in this position as it is largely devoid of lichen encrustation and bears marks which appear to be machine lacerations. A semi-derelict house which is unoccupied is within sight of the stone circle 55m to SSE. Expansive views are afforded from the stone circle towards Mullaghanattin at N and NE. Due to modern dykes and ditches around the the circle as well as forestry and other vegetation, the circle itself is largely obscured from view other than from within close range.  A kerb circle in Gortacloghane (KE091-015001) is located 2.1km to ENE.Compiled by: Aoibheann Lambe Date of upload/revision: 10 November 2021

Within the SW end of a cairn associated with a possible unclassified megalithic tomb (CL009-021012-). A circle of seven upright stones (H c. 0.4m) encloses a small fairly level area (c. 2.5m NW–SE; c. 2m NE–SW). In the centre of this space a large roughly rectangular slab (1.3m NW–SE; NE–SW 0.95m) lies flat. A possible cist (CL009-021059-) lies to the S of the chamber of the tomb. Both of these features suggest that the possible tomb was subsequently reused. (Grant 2010)Compiled by: Olive Alcock and Conn HerriottRevised by: Olive AlcockDate of upload: 6 January 2022
